feed.title: Mere Code - Comments: Explaining Version Control to Non-Programmers

entry.title: Posted by: spiv (noreply@blogger.com)
entry.summary: I tell them that I work on a tool that helps programmers collaborate. That's a bit abstract and vague (lots of different kinds of tools could do that), but somewhat comprehensible.

entry.title: Posted by: jml (noreply@blogger.com)
entry.summary: Yeah, that's what I end up saying as well. But, I'd like to have something better in reserve for people who are interested enough to know details.

entry.title: Posted by: Bice Dibley (noreply@blogger.com)
entry.summary: Depends on who I'm talking to, but I have described version control as "Like track changes in Word, but for hundreds of documents at once." It's not really true, but it does get people into the right ballpark.

entry.title: Posted by: Gary van der Merwe (noreply@blogger.com)
entry.summary:
I ask them if they have ever edited Wikipedia, and if they have, I point out version control features in Wikipedia to them, and how they help people to collaborate.

For programmers that are new to version control, I point them to http://www.ericsink.com/scm/source_control.html which is and excellent and comprehensive guide to version control. It is pre-dvcs, so it could do with an update.
